td.a: April 17: Superintendent's Weekly Update to Families & Staff
td.br: The Appoquinimink School District continues to issue families and staff regular updates on the COVID-19 situation using the email address on file for your household. Open this story for a copy of the message that was launched on April 17, 2020.

td.a: HEALTHCARE PROFESSIONALS WEAR MASKS ALL DAY. THEY'RE NOT COMFORTABLE. USING A 3-D PRINTER TEACHER BRIAN CLIFTON IS DOING SOMETHING ABOUT IT!

img.br: Engineering teacher Brian Clifton was looking for ways to support area healthcare professionals when he discovered a design for a simple, yet effective ear guard that could be produced using a 3-D printer like the ones in his classroom at Alfred G. Waters Middle School. The guard acts as a buffer to prevent the painful rubbing associated with long shifts wearing masks attached by elastic bands behind the ears. It's efficient design features a series of notches along a central strap that allow the wearer to adjust the tension while keeping the mask firmly in place. The colorful bands are made from polylactic acid ​(PLA), a plastic material commonly used for 3D printing. Each strap takes about 25 minutes to print with a material investment of $0.08 each. The design he's using can be found on the open-source 3-D printing community Thingiverse, https://www.thingiverse.com. It was created by 12-year old inventor Quinn Callander, who lives in Vancouver, Canada. STORY CONTINUES...

td.br: On April 9, Appoquinimink hosted a virtual meeting (it's second) to update the MOT and Bear Communities about the District’s COVID-19 response. ​​​​​​​The meeting featured presentations about the status of ASD’s remote learning program – an effort that kicked off on March 30, 2020 – and information about calendar adjustments necessitated by the closure of schools. Note: Pending an unforeseen circumstance, the last day of school will now be June 1, 2020 for Seniors and June 11, 2020 for Grade KG-11 students. Story continues...
